posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: During the playoffs at the 10,000K Lakes Regional, a collision with a defense bot caused the 5V rail on our RIO/DIO ports to fail. We likely won’t pursue replacing it or taking further action since the new robot controller is expected shortly. Instead, we discovered we can use our VRM (Voltage Regulator Module) for just the power supply. Wondering if this is a common failure mode?

posts.name: Aaron
posts.cooked: 10,000,000 lakes, Anyways, are there any differences in the status lights or faults for the RIO on the Driver Station?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 4269 Student Captain and Electrical Lead

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Here’s a cleaned-up version of your text:

This can happen if the 5v rail is shorted to ground or another source like 12v.  
The power source isn’t highly fault-tolerant, leading to metal shavings from drilling during installation sometimes causing problems.  
Some teams have been fortunate and resolved the issue by thoroughly cleaning their devices.  
Others have repeatedly cleaned but now face permanent damage to their source circuits, requiring alternative solutions.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: No difference in status lights; the primary issue with the RIO is the 5V.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: We did have metal shavings at one time, and we removed them by vacuuming. Although you might think so, even though the issue was delayed after that point, it could have potentially caused permanent damage.

ARio has encountered a Rio with an issue on its 5V rail. After installing limit switches at the first COMP station, one wire was connected to the signal and another to the 5V rail. Since the DIO pin includes an internal pull-up resistor, this configuration should not work. Surprisingly, however, the Rio functioned as intended until it failed during testing in one of our practice fields. Debugging later revealed that the failure led to an unrecoverable error, ultimately resulting in a power fault.
The color of your power status light indicates whether a chip is shorted in the ports. If it's red, this suggests a chip is shorted. If it's green, further investigation is needed.

link_counts.title: Status Light Quick Reference — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Issac Woo
posts.cooked: Try unscrewing your roboRIO apart and carefully use vacuuming and isopropyl alcohol to clean anything inside. You can expect to find a surprising amount of dust inside!

Something similar happened to us. Our RSL port, abbreviated as RSL, suddenly stopped functioning during the competition. All the ports on the Rio were covered with electrical tape, making unauthorized access impossible.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: This can happen if the 5V rail is shorted to ground or another source, such as 12V. The power source isn’t extremely fault-tolerant, which often leads to issues like metal shavings from drilling during installation causing problems. I’m curious if there are more fault-tolerant devices than the roboRIO, particularly regarding whether they continue to operate a specific pin when a direct short occurs. To me, the ability to clean out debris without releasing harmful fumes suggests higher fault tolerance compared to most devices.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Off-highway vehicle controllers (consumer market, not industrial). Although similar in design to the roboRIO, their requirements differ. Every I/O pin is individually short-to-high and short-to-ground fault tolerant, including external 5V sources connected short-to-battery. If a fault is detected, the pin is typically returned to a neutral/off state to avoid potential safety risks.

There are rare corner cases where shorting two pins simultaneously—a high and ground connection on separate pins—can create a dangerous dead short across an output driver chip. However, this scenario is uncommon. In some instances, individuals have recovered from metal shaving incidents by cleaning affected areas. As a student, I experienced several instances where students shorted the battery, causing supply rail failures. 

While every electronic system has design limits, the cRio improved upon these aspects compared to earlier versions. However, I am impressed with the new '27 control system, which is 100% S2H/S2G pin tested. This level of electrical circuit design and validation aligns well with the FIRST teaching environment.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text, formatted as requested:

---

Did you know you can jump-start a medium-sized motor grader using an arc welder? Our team has successfully created a fried 5v rail issue twice over the past four years. Despite thorough cleaning, the problem remains unresolved. This issue is frustratingly persistent. After four years of trying, things still don’t improve.

---

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
The text has been cleaned up and reformatted below to meet your requirements:

There are 10 million lakes in the United States. Y know, OP, there’s a common misconception that Wisconsin has more lakes than Minnesota.  

**Technical Advice:**  
Unplug everything from the Robot Integral Override (RIO) except for power before testing. If you measure 5V, something is shorting the circuit. Identify the cause and repair it before plugging anything back in. RIOs are robust but fragile, so handle them with care.  

**Preventative Measures:**  
If you suspect a wiring issue, check for shorts in the components connected to the RIO. Metal shavings can cause unintended shorts. Avoid using the RIO indefinitely; replace faulty boards and inspect wiring thoroughly. For ESD safety, prefer wet wipes over brushes or cloths when cleaning.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Perhaps I'm wrong, but if I recall two years ago, we opened up our Rio with a fried 5v bus from a short to battery, and most of the board had conformal-coated areas with sufficient thickness.

I completely agree to switch to a different approach and investigate the issue further, though I wonder if thick layers of metal shavings beyond the mechanical openings could pose any problems.

I remember that the conformal coating didn’t cover inside the I/O pins or near the mechanical openings, but it did start applying a few millimeters beyond these points.

It’s also possible that I confused this with another component I’ve examined lately.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

Everyone is surprised by the 32v jump-start voltage levels for a 12v system or charging system load-dump transients. Have you ever seen welders used in the field to get yourself home?

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text, formatted as requested:

---

32v jump start voltage levels for a 12v system, or charging system load dump transients!

Quite to the dismay of automotive electronics engineers everywhere… And Brandon Hjelstrom.

On a separate note, I sure hope the new Mobile Robot Controller is like potted or something. I think the roboRIO is especially bad with the giant gaps in the plastic around the DIO, but I wonder if material sneaks through the small gaps around the other ports? We tape over everything and still get internal shorts. Perhaps our elevator is generating especially tiny particulate.

We already know it won’t have sealed industrial/automotive connectors which is a bit disappointing (no one really uses them in FIRST though), but at least if they use actual Molex SL connectors instead of a header strip, there isn’t as much of a gaping hole in the case.

I’m not sure why it’s only the RIO we ever have this issue with, maybe the conformal coating is too thin or something? We weren’t just getting the 5V short fault, it wasn’t even booting until we took it apart and blew it out.

---

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: We finally got back in the shop yesterday. We apparently missed a metal shaving on the machine—it was stuck in deep. We missed vacuuming it out. Instead, we used compressed air to blow it out, and the issue is now fixed.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked: The RoboRIO has internal overcurrent protection on its 5V DIO ports and 6V PWM ports. Metal shavings in these ports can cause further damage to the electronics in the case. We tape all exposed openings to prevent debris from entering. Between events, we clean the case by opening it after sealing the Rio. Surprisingly, even a well-sealed Rio can develop debris within the case itself.
